question: Question_01_(a)
statement:
Let $S_1$ be the plane perpendicular to $\mathbf{n}=[2,1,-1]$ and
through the point P={[}1,-1,0{]}. Let $S_2$ be the plane through the
points A={[}1,0,0{]}, B={[}-1,2,1{]}, C={[}0,1,1{]}. By L, we denote the
line of intersection of $S_1$ and $S_2$.

Determine the planes $S_1$ and $S_2$ in equation form.
sols:
For the first plane $S_1$ we know that its normal is
$\mathbf{n}=[2,1,-1]$ as this is provided. We$^{\prime}$re also told
that the point $P=[1,-1,0]$ is on the plane. Using this information we
can easily get the equation for $S_1$ via

\begin{align*}
0&=\mathbf{n}\cdot\left(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{P}\right)\\
&=[2,1,-1]\cdot[x_1-1,x_2+1,x_3]\\
&=2x_2+x_2-x_3-1.
\end{align*}

We have to work a little harder to get the equation for the plane of
$S_2$. However, notice we are given three points that are on the plane.
Let $\mathbf{u}=\vec{AB}$ be the vector connecting A to B and
$\mathbf{v}=\vec{AC}$ be the vector connecting A to C. We therefore have
that,

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{u}=B-A&=[-2,2,1]\\
\mathbf{v}=C-A&=[-1,1,1].
\end{align*}

We know that the normal to the plane is orthogonal to all vectors on the
plane. Since $\mathbf{u}$ and $\mathbf{v}$ are on the plane, if we take
their cross product, we will get a vector orthogonal to both
$\mathbf{u}$ and $\mathbf{v}$ and thus be orthogonal to the plane. Call
this vector $\mathbf{m}$,

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{m}&=\mathbf{u}\times\mathbf{v}\\
&=[-2,2,1]\times[-1,1,1]\\
&=\textrm{det}
\begin{pmatrix}
\mathbf{i}  &  \mathbf{j}  &  \mathbf{k}\\
-2  &  2  &  1\\
-1  &  1  &  1
\end{pmatrix}\\
&=[1,1,0].
\end{align*}

We can now use this normal vector along with any point on the plane to
get the equation. We will use $\mathbf{a}=[1,0,0]$,

\begin{align*}
0=\mathbf{m}\cdot(\mathbf{x}-\mathbf{a})=[1,1,0]\cdot[x_1-1,x_2,x_3]=x_1+x_2-1.
\end{align*}

Therefore, we get that the equation for $S_1$ is $2x_1+x_2-x_3-1=0$
while the equation for $S_2$ is $x_1+x_2-1=0$.
hints:
Recall that in order to define a plane, we need a normal vector and a
point on the plane.
